DataElement.preferredDefinition: The Code for the sex of the patient.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: statistical characterization of human populations (or segments of human populations broken down by age or sex or income etc.).

Concepts.definition: The statistical characterization of human populations or segments of human populations (e.g., characterization by age, sex, race, or income).

Property.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.:The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female. (from On-line Medical Dictionary)

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.
The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ValueDomain.preferredName: Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End ResultsProgram /Commision on Cancer Person Sex Number Code
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A cancer registry mandated under the National Cancer Act of 1971 to operate and maintain a population-based cancer reporting system, reporting periodically estimates of cancer incidence and mortality in the United States. The Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program is a continuing project of the National Cancer Institute of the National Institutes of Health. Among its goals, in addition to assembling and reporting cancer statistics, are the monitoring of annual cancer incident trends and the promoting of studies designed to identify factors amenable to cancer control interventions. (From a brochure of the National Cancer Institute, NIH Publication No. 91-3074, October 1990)_Commission on Cancer (COC)_Person; a human being._The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female. (from On-line Medical Dictionary)_Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification._A system, often of numbered categories, for representation of data

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A person who was assigned to one gender at birth based on physical characteristics but who self-identifies psychologically and emotionally as the other.: The physical sexual characteristics of the neonate at birth.: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.

Concepts.definition: A person who was assigned to one gender at birth based on physical characteristics but who self-identifies psychologically and emotionally as the other.
The physical sexual characteristics of the neonate at birth.
A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program Person Sex Number Code
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A cancer registry mandated under the National Cancer Act of 1971 to operate and maintain a population-based cancer reporting system, reporting periodically estimates of cancer incidence and mortality in the United States. The Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program is a continuing project of the National Cancer Institute of the National Institutes of Health. Among its goals, in addition to assembling and reporting cancer statistics, are the monitoring of annual cancer incident trends and the promoting of studies designed to identify factors amenable to cancer control interventions. (From a brochure of the National Cancer Institute, NIH Publication No. 91-3074, October 1990):Person; a human being.:The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female. (from On-line Medical Dictionary):Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.longName: Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program
Concepts.definition: A program of the National Cancer Institute that provides information on cancer statistics in an effort to reduce the cancer burden among the U.S. population.
A human being.
The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female.
A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
